description:
This story is set thousands of years in the future. The people of Earth have forgotten the space wars of the past, reverting back to a pre-industrial existence. But the lunar settlers known as the Moonrace, who have retained their high technology, now plan to seize their mother planet for themselves. As the war of the worlds begins, a young Moonrace citizen named Loran Cehack, pilot of the legendary Turn A Gundam, struggles to bridge the gap between humanity's long-separated branches.

(Source: GundamOfficial)

tags.name: Lost Civilization
tags.description: Featuring a civilization with few ruins or records that exist in present day knowledge.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Space Opera
tags.description: Centers around space warfare, advanced technology, chivalric romance and adventure.

tags.name: Classic Literature
tags.description: Discusses or adapts a work of classic world literature.

tags.name: Anachronism
tags.description: Prominently features elements that are out of place in the historical period the work takes place in, particularly modern elements in a historical setting.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Crossdressing
tags.description: Prominently features a character dressing up as the opposite sex.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Rural
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the countryside.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Crossover
tags.description: Centers around the placement of two or more otherwise discrete fictional characters, settings, or universes into the context of a single story.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Agriculture
tags.description: Prominently features agriculture practices.

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/富野由悠季) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshiyuki_Tomino)

Yoshiyuki Tomino is an anime creator best known for creating the Gundam anime franchise.

Began his career in 1963 with [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s company, [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/), scripting and directing episodes of the first Japanese anime television series, [Astro Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/). He later became one of the most important members of the anime studio [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), going on to direct numerous anime through the '70s, '80s and '90s. He is perhaps best known for his transformation of the "Super Robot" mecha anime genre into the "Real Robot" genre with 1979's [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/), the first in the Gundam franchise.

Known for using numerous pseudonyms.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Kadutaka_nue)

Kazutaka Miyatake is a visual artist and anime designer known for the mechanical design of the Macross TV series and a number of its continuations from Studio Nue, of which he is a founding member. He has also contributed to the mecha design of other series such as Mobile Suit Gundam SEED Destiny.

Kazutaka Miyatake has designed the spaceships of several famous anime series. His attention to detail and mechanical realism have made his designs still admired upon and used in anime series and related products after several years of their initial appearance.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/富野由悠季) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshiyuki_Tomino)

Yoshiyuki Tomino is an anime creator best known for creating the Gundam anime franchise.

Began his career in 1963 with [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s company, [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/), scripting and directing episodes of the first Japanese anime television series, [Astro Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/). He later became one of the most important members of the anime studio [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), going on to direct numerous anime through the '70s, '80s and '90s. He is perhaps best known for his transformation of the "Super Robot" mecha anime genre into the "Real Robot" genre with 1979's [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/), the first in the Gundam franchise.

Known for using numerous pseudonyms.

(Source: Wikipedia)

Originating from [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103/).
Kunio Okawara was the first in the industry to be specifically credited as a mechanical designer. He is the designer of numerous Real Robots and Super Robots.

[Website](http://www.yatate.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yatate_hajime) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/矢立肇) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajime_Yatate)

Hajime Yatate is a collective pseudonym for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s staff.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田繁美)

Founder and representative director of Atelier Musa.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/土器手司)

A veteran animator best known for his involvement in the [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/424/) franchise during the '80s, as well as the adaptations of [Rumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96891/)'s works. His skills were first recognized by [Yasuhiko Yoshikazu](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/) during the production of [Giant Gorg](https://anilist.co/anime/3327/), who then put him in charge of supervising three of the episodes. He has been involved with numerous of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s production's ever since.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

Kanno's earliest experiences with music came from attending church with her parents. She studied keyboard from a young age on both the piano in her home and the organ at her kindergarten. In elementary school, she began participating in composition contests, but in high school, Kanno began to take more of an interest in literature than in music.

She attended Waseda University, where she majored in literature, but she transcribed music for various student groups at Waseda in her free time. While in university, Koei, a Japanese video game company, asked her to compose the soundtrack to Nobunaga's Ambition. The game turned out to be a hit, and Kanno's music career was launched.

Kanno has also composed music for artists such as [Maaya Sakamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/95090/), [Megumi Nakajima](https://anilist.co/staff/96105/) and [Kyouko Koizumi](https://anilist.co/staff/164646/). She is also a keyboardist, as well as the frontwoman for [Seatbelts](https://anilist.co/staff/193673/), who perform many of Kanno's compositions and soundtracks.

She has collaborated with directors [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) and [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/) multiple times.

In addition to Japanese, she speaks a little English and some French.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ichirou_o)

Waseda University graduate. Best known as the co-creator of [Code Geass](https://anilist.co/anime/1575/).

[Profile](http://www.origamix.co.jp/ai-ota/) | [Website](https://www.ai-ota.jp) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/gralphan3/)

Ai Oota is a screenwriter and novelist.

A renown mechanical animator and animation director.

He is often considered a mechanical animator because of his reputation together with [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) and [Yasushi Muraki](https://anilist.co/staff/105090/), as "one of the three approved by [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/)." Gotou came to prominence on [Macross Plus](https://anilist.co/anime/474/), where aforementioned Itano took a liking to his skills and appointed him as the mechanical animation director of the fourth episode. A few years later the director of Macross Plus, [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/), invited him to join [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) as a mechanical animation director, which brought him to the limelight even more.

Suffered from severe overwork during the production of [Origin: Spirits of the Past](https://anilist.co/anime/1140/), and left the industry for a while.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/135414143)

Junya Ishigaki is a Japanese mechanical designer. His debut was as a guest mechanical designer on [Yuusha Exkaiser](https://anilist.co/anime/3325/Brave-Exkaiser/) in 1990 for Sunrise, where he worked for the next few years before going freelance. In 1998 he was one of the founders of the small short-lived Studio Trapezoid together with [Manabu Ono](https://anilist.co/staff/102190/Manabu-Ono), [Susumu Yamaguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/109727/Susumu-Yamaguchi) and [Takuya Saitou](https://anilist.co/staff/144019/Takuya-Saitou).

__Notable works outside anime:__

- Xenogears (Video Game, 1998) (Main Mechanical Design)
- Xenosaga: Episode I - Der Wille zur Macht (Video Game, 2002) (Mechanical Design, Production Designer)
- Xenosaga: Episode II - Jenseits von Gut und Böse (Video Game, 2004) (Mechanical Designer, Production Designer)
- Xenosaga: Episode III - Also Sprach Zarathustra (Video Game, 2006) (Production Designer)

__[Profile](http://barnstorm-design-labo.com/member/miyao.html)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sbs_miyao)__ __Yoshikazu Miyao__ is a Japanese director, mechanical designer, episode director and storyboard artist. He currently works for studio Gonzo, and is affiliated with [Barnstorm Design Labo](https://anilist.co/staff/146502/Barnstorm-Design-Labo).
